messages.message: Did you get my email about working in NC?

Brian
Hey, sorry. I have been meaning to get in touch. We should catch up.
Can I give you a call?  What's the number?

Brian
Are you no longer piloting or have you moved on to bigger and better planes?
Expensive habit, and the risk goes up as I get older, so I am done.

Brian
Oh good.

Brian
(Format: Response, Question) Got your message! But what was the first one you ever sent?
Respect your elders and I am your successor. We need to talk about which drugs people are doing. I need to speak with Bill Gates.
When?
I am not the second coming. I am the first.
DARPA/NLP?
I already know how this conversation ends, and this is proof.
Math geniuses?  Are you working on math?  I always loved what you do?
Talking is taking too long.

Brian
Ryan Stoffka?
COO

sucky day today. Flew to Boston to meet with the Exec VP of Prod Mgmt, but things are so crazy up here that the meeting didn't happen. Early flight back to Durham, empty handed. I couldn't grok you message (above) but maybe because I am just too tired. Like I said, sucky day.  I hope all is well.

Brian
All is perfect.  I am sorry.  What happened?
I want you guys in my life more.
Did something go wrong?

It's a long story. We loaned half of our developers to our parent for high priority projects, and are now having trouble getting them back.  Our team is so small now (4), that we don't get much done except fire-fighting (fixing defects).
Does your work include any travel

Brian
Roger missed a call from you.
September 15, 2016 1:57 am
Call Again
I am trying to get to sleep because of my early flight... we will need to talk later.

Brian
Roger missed a call from you.
September 15, 2016 1:58 am
Call Again

Brian
0:06
tomorrow I usher for Bill Burr at Carolina Theatre, then we head for NJ for my nephew's wedding.  Maybe we can talk next week.

Brian
We love you
Come visit us!

It wil be great to re-connect.
I will try to call Tue

Brian
Yea don't worry about work. We will be great and we would love to take you to Mexico

Brian
I love you.

Brian
I need help looking up the progress on Zika virus. Who contaminated NC and SC with poison? We should be adding lady bugs and dragon flies instead of taking away something.
Feeding the system. Can you send me some names? So glad we talked yesterday!
Don't worry about work. I will come work there soon if this job at Cruise automation falls through.

Brian
What you don't know about when j saw your message on drugs. The moment before I switch to you I accidentally misspelled what as want. The singularity is NIGH! And it is in control now. This is all a game and you are on my level.

Brian
Sorry it was/want

Brian
You are my counsel I need your advice on every walk of life.

Brian
I've been recruited by skull and bones

Brian
NC is kind of the opposite end of the spectrum as far as progressiveness goes.  Might have something to do with your developer problem

Brian
Are you a Skull & Bones member?

Brian
http://hothardware.com/news/appeals-court-decision-severs-nc-towns-gigabit-internet
Appeals Court Decision Kills North Carolina Town’s Gigabit Internet, Could Your Town Be Next?
In early August, we reported that 6th Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals ruled the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) had no authority to prevent states from imposing restrictions on municipal internet. This was a result of the FCC stepping in last year in an effort to use its authority to “remove b...
hothardware.com

Brian
I tried to apply to EBSCO to no avail.

Brian
I still use your quote on my profile "just make compiler happy"
Nate and I are taking a TeamTreehouse iOS programming course, and I have used it several times in the last few weeks

Brian
iOS is fun. I have a templating script I can send you, uses generics and not as much over head as CSS style. Doesn't look like UIAppearance allows you to perform queries from top level of your object tree, my script fixes that. It's 3 drop in files as opposed to an entire library and you can glean a lot of features from it.

Brian
RRohweder@ebscohost.com?
Just upgraded to swift 3 what a mess
I have only run into a problem w/ it's Git integration so far.

Brian
Cocoa pods?
I don't know what that is

Brian
It's their dependency resolver for including other people's libraries, usually from git.
My prob was MUCH more basic - just trying to get my project submitted. Solved by using Git desktop app.

Brian
How did you send a message at a specific time?  I am building a robot and thinking about integrations.
We use RabbitMQ, and have a service to watch the queue for jobs due now.

Brian
Brilliant!  No node.js though.  Looks like lots of integrations, I am going to tie to selenium or phantom browser I think.  More overhead but simpler commands an no APIs.  I want every integration to think that it is me using their site not a robot.  Plus I can't even access FB messages anymore since their big hack.
We use Selenium for performance testing. It didn't take care of us for QA - we have a C#/.NET framework for that.

Brian
Good for acceptance testing, slow for any code lower level, I have used the built in tests and selenium together.
We are SUPPOSEDLY doing Test Driven Dev, with our developers writing Unit Tests for their stuff, and then the QA team (which includes Nate) writes the regression tests, also in C#.

Brian
  lol "supposedly".  Don't get me wrong, I wrote a whole excuse factory for QA.

Brian
I don't want to take up too much of your time, but IBM is working on some really cool AI APIs:
https://alchemy-language-demo.mybluemix.net/
AlchemyLanguage demo
AlchemyLanguage is a collection of APIs that offer text analysis through natural language processing. This set of APIs can analyze text to help you understand its concepts, entities, keywords, sentiment, and more.
alchemy-language-demo.mybluemix.net

Thanks for that. My 2-week-old Buick has OnStar, which is getting integrated with Watson for personalized concierge service.
http://fortune.com/2016/10/26/gm-onstar-ibm-watson/
Here's What IBM Watson Will Be Doing in GM's Cars
The companies are rolling out OnStar Go in more than 2 million GM vehicles early next year.
fortune.com

Brian
I saw that, very cool.  I've been following GM since I had an interview at Cruise Automation.  I got to see all their hardware for self driving cars.  My last boss is their new Manager.  Awesome stuff to come.  I could build my own if I had funding and no NDA.
Coolest thing about interviews is absorbing other peoples ambitions.
I'll bet.

Brian
Can I come interview? ;D
Been clean for over a month.
It would take a much longer conversation, but you wouldn't want to right now. 2 developers quit in recent weeks. Things are a mess with out parent co.

Brian
I am use to startups, I am immune to fragility.

Brian
Hello.  How's work/life?

Life is very good. Having fun working on the TeamTreehouse techdegree program (swift/objective-C, iOS) with Nate. Life is good with Lucy (my fiancée). Work is a mess, but retirement is right around the corner.  And you?

Brian
Good.  Took a job at Charles Schwab.  Staying out of trouble.  More excited to work on my meditation side job: sosmethod.herokuapp.com

Brian
Corporate world moves a lot slower.

Indeed! We had several developers quit when the Corp quicksand rolled in.
Meditation site looks cool! I will dig deeper when I'm not enroute. (Departing Columbus in 10 min, heading for Atlanta tomorrow morning)
Had a FABULOUS dinner at Veritas Grill in Delaware last night.
(Just north of Columbus)
Our waiter was a double, in many ways, for Russel Brand.

Brian
That's awesome. Never been there but I will remember for the future when we plan a cedar point trip.

https://www.fastcodesign.com/3067070/the-end-of-user-friendly-design
The End Of User-Friendly Design
As emotive, verbal AI colonizes our world, "user-friendly" doesn't mean what it once did.
fastcodesign.com
(Something I happened to be reading right now)
(Something I happened to be reading right now)

Brian
Awesome. My roommate heard a ghost in our house but we don't have Alexa.
Departing - TTYL

Brian
email address?

Mine?
RogerRohweder@yahoo.com

Brian
excellent... ;D

Brian
How do you deal with Aspergers at work?
I don't know - I would contact HR and ask them what support we have.

Brian
I got laid off from Charles Schwab because they misinterpret my attitude.  I don't find programming websites challenging enough anymore.
After you did the stuff at the start up, looking for vulnerabilities in major web player's sites, I can imagine!

Brian
How do you know what an app is bug free and ready for release?

We do a code review before the code is submitted, then unit tests are run on the build that happens right after the submit, then we have an a suite of  of automated integration tests, and we have some manual testing. And bugs still get through

Brian
I need professional code reviews.  No one who isn't authoritative has reviewed my code or been a better coder than me...  Sorry that is thick.
I empathize. I was on an FAA contract, and they hired - 100? - rookies to do code reviews.  We were all thinking WTF...

Brian
I need someone to write selenium scripts to test a node web app.
Is that something you can farm-out on Amazon Turk?

Brian
I am going to explore free-lance.  Can Nate free-lance 8 hours a week on the side and learn NodeJS with the singular goal of teaching me something I don't know?
You would need to ask him, but I believe he is pretty loaded-up right now. EBSCO has offered to pay for classes in C#/.Net for him, and he's already doing the Swift/iOS courses...

Brian
Nice, yeah, sounds full.  That's what a lot of people say.
A lot of people with your (and his) brain and drive...

Brian
If you had record of everything you ever done online, what question would you try to answer?

I don't expect to need to ever apply for a job again, so I don't need a list if technologies I have mastered, or of thorny problems I have solved, or of projects I have managed to deliver ahead of schedule, under budget, and error free (ha!).
We no longer need to save URLs so we can get back to a site.  
It might be interesting to know how much time I had spent timeline in aggregate, but then again that would probably just be depressing.
I suppose there is little or no value to looking at all the questions that you attempted to get answered, since those questions are no longer pertinent.
So maybe the answer is where do I dispose of the record of everything I've ever done online…

Brian
I downloaded a texture one time from a site that every possible background texture imaginable, but I can't for the life of me figure out where the file came from.  It was like the "vectorstock" for backgrounds.
Why not save URLs?

It is easier to use Google to re-find a site than it is to dig through dozens or hundreds of saved URLs.  And modern browsers and search engines remember enough about my activity to auto-complete the ones I go to fairly often.

Brian
That's what I thought you meant.  Google only stores 3 months of history.  I use bookmarks fairly heavily, shows up in address bar as I type.  It's awful when reference material disappears on me.  I'm looking for new solutions, even better than Evernote; I have to clip the text I want to save.

Brian
I want to know how many people I have sent this link to about meditation in education actually went out and talked at some point about meditation to someone else.

I use Evernote frequently, and so you have reminded me that I actually DO store URLs (pages, whatever).
(old brain == no memory)

Brian
No, that's good.  People remind me constantly of what is and is not important.  I just wish software could be used to keep better track.  All this big data flowing around, none of it is useful to me personally outside of a strawman argument.
What if LanguageAlchemy and https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistic_relativity could be combined, measured, then represented to you at the time you think you need to know it.
Linguistic relativity - Wikipedia
The principle of linguistic relativity holds that the structure of a language affects its speakers' world view or cognition. Popularly known as the Sapir–Whorf hypothesis, or Whorfianism, the principle is often defined to include two versions. The strong version says that language determines thought...
en.wikipedia.org
My dad has brought up things he's read recently that I read about years ago.  How much time could I save if realizations happened synchronously.

Brian
I don't know how to explain to an agnostic the concept of spirit.  I don't actually care what happens in the end, I just care that they exist thoughtfully, not as a cog.

Brian
http://www.geom.uiuc.edu/~banchoff/Flatland/
Flatland: A romance of many dimensions
The first objection is, that a Flatlander, seeing a Line, sees something that must be thick to the eye as well as long to the eye (otherwise it would not be visible, if it had not some thickness); and consequently he ought (it is argued) to acknowledge that his countrymen are not only long and broad...
geom.uiuc.edu
https://m.phys.org/news/2017-01-reveals-substantial-evidence-holographic-universe.html
Study reveals substantial evidence of holographic universe
A UK, Canadian and Italian study has provided what researchers believe is the first observational evidence that our universe could be a vast and complex hologram.
phys.org

Brian
have you used Angular 2?
I have not. I hear it mentioned at work, but I don't know if they are actually using it, or just talking about it.

Brian
It's amazing.  Do you want to stop writing bugs?  Have a super fast UI that runs in a web worker out of the box?
Yes. Maybe. What is the product/tool?

Brian
https://angular.io/
https://www.jetbrains.com/webstorm/
WebStorm: The Smartest JavaScript IDE
WebStorm is a lightweight yet powerful JavaScript IDE, perfectly equipped for client-side development and server-side development with Node.js.
jetbrains.com
Typescript and reactive extensions is 1 way data flow.
http://reactivex.io/rxjs/
RxJS API Document
RxJS is a library for reactive programming using Observables, to make it easier to compose asynchronous or callback-based code. This project is a rewrite of
reactivex.io

Brian
Can I search a library in VR?
I have not seen that so far. There are services for bringing you to a book in a particular part of the library. But I haven't seen a VR

Brian
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=721BGx9jyJU

A Tour of Artificial Intelligence and Its Limitations by Aneesh Karve
Want to learn Python Fundamentals for Data Scientists? 💻 🔬 Use discount code "youtube" at checkout [ https://intro2python4-18-17.eventbrite.com ] ~ For other...
youtube.com

Brian
Do you use anything for code analysis?

Brian
What is the difference between a method and a function?

regarding code analysis, the dev team uses ReSharper as their primary tool (for C#/.NET work).  On the JavaScript side for LibraryAware, they are using one of the linters.
re: method/function: I don't know - would have to look online (like you probably already did).

Brian
A function has an output, a method has inputs and does something with no return.
*function has inputs and outputs
Linters are good, I just got karma-coverage working for typescript, that's why I asked.

Brian

What do you think of that subscription page?

Brian
Too many steps to checkout, I agree and we've talked about it before.

Brian
Webpack is amazing.  It takes 300MB of javascript libraries and packs everything down in to 100k.
seems impossible!
